fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30661].
  {panel}

I would like the ability to have global transitions that cross multiple workflows, and the ability to edit a transition and have it take place across multiple workflows.

It is inevitable that projects will have their own necessary workflow but what is common are the transitions that are used, whether it is a custom one, or one that is provided out of the box.  I would like the ability to use a true global transition that would allow me to define specific behavior no matter what workflow is used. Of course, I could retain the ability to have a localized transition for that workflow.

Example:

After running JIRA for nearly a year, we have had a new growth of users, projects, and workflows. It was requested, several times, that we zero out the remaining estimate when closing an issue. Since this change is global, I had to edit each customized workflow to include this post function. That was very time consuming.

In the future we plan to introduce software approvals via the workflow. Each customized workflow will have to have all the approval transitions and statuses added. If a change of any kind is needed, each customized workflow using those transitions must be modified.

In the above example, it would be great to set true global transitions so that I can add the "Approved for Beta" status on the design form, and drag the transition (which I have already set properties, conditions, validations, and post functions for) between my two preferred states. This way, if it was determined that we wanted a new post function to happen globally, I can go to one place, make my change, and have it become active across all workflows that use that true global transition.

Another great method is to have sub-workflows. Using the same software approval example; The approval process will start after the Resolved status and before Closed. I would like to add the "Approval sub-workflow" to start from the Resolved state. In the design view, I look at my available sub-workflows, select the Approval sub-workflow and drag it to the Resolved state. All the statuses and transitions the sub-workflow contains will be copied over. During the copy I will be prompted to choose to copy locally, or keep the sub-workflow linked globally (global means I modify the sub-workflow - all workflows and projects that use it is changed).  This method goes one step better than global transitions as an entire portion of the workflow can be added and I can maintain a 'change once, apply everywhere' mantra.

If there is currently a method to achieve what I want, please let me know.

Thanks!

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30643].
  {panel}

h3. Summary: 

If the default {{jira}} workflow is copied and a transition is cloned with a different name, the cloned name will appear in the issue view screen for the transition buttons.
E.g when I clone a transition, and specify a new name, the new transition keeps the old transition's name, so I have two (for example) 'Start Progress' buttons.

h3. Steps to Reproduce:

# Copy the {{jira}} system workflow.
# Edit it with the workflow designer.
# Add a new transition, cloning the Start Progress Transition, providing it with a different name.
# Create a new workflow scheme, assigning the new workflow to it and then assign it to a project.
# View an issue in the appropriate status for that transition. The transition will not have the new name.

h3. Expected Results:

The transition has the name as defined within the workflow designer.

h3. Actual Results:

The new transition has the name of the cloned transition. This appears to be caused by cloning the following elements:
{code:XML}
          <meta name="opsbar-sequence">20</meta>
          <meta name="jira.i18n.title">stopprogress.title</meta>
{code}

h3. Regression:

Not a regression. This is not existant in the ViewWorkflowSteps.jspa editor as that functionality is not available. Tested back to 4.4.5 and this was present.

h3. Notes:

XML of a transition created from scratch:
{code:XML}
        <action id="731" name="New Transition">
          <meta name="jira.description"></meta>
          <results>
            <unconditional-result old-status="Not Done" status="Done" step="3">
              <post-functions>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.issue.UpdateIssueStatusFunction</arg>
                </function>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.misc.CreateCommentFunction</arg>
                </function>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.issue.GenerateChangeHistoryFunction</arg>
                </function>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.issue.IssueReindexFunction</arg>
                </function>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.event.FireIssueEventFunction</arg>
                  <arg name="eventTypeId">13</arg>
                </function>
              </post-functions>
            </unconditional-result>
          </results>
        </action>
{code}

XML of a cloned transition:
{code:XML}
        <action id="711" name="I HAS A DIFFERENT NAME">
          <meta name="opsbar-sequence">20</meta>
          <meta name="jira.i18n.title">stopprogress.title</meta>
          <meta name="jira.description"></meta>
          <restrict-to>
            <conditions>
              <condition type="class">
                <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.condition.AllowOnlyAssignee</arg>
              </condition>
            </conditions>
          </restrict-to>
          <results>
            <unconditional-result old-status="Not Done" status="Done" step="4">
              <post-functions>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.issue.UpdateIssueFieldFunction</arg>
                  <arg name="field.value"></arg>
                  <arg name="field.name">resolution</arg>
                </function>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.issue.UpdateIssueStatusFunction</arg>
                </function>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.misc.CreateCommentFunction</arg>
                </function>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.issue.GenerateChangeHistoryFunction</arg>
                </function>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.issue.IssueReindexFunction</arg>
                </function>
                <function type="class">
                  <arg name="class.name">com.atlassian.jira.workflow.function.event.FireIssueEventFunction</arg>
                  <arg name="eventTypeId">12</arg>
                </function>
              </post-functions>
            </unconditional-result>
          </results>
        </action>
{code}

h3. Workaround:

To update the title of the button, Please follow the steps below:

# Choose Cog > Issues
# Choose 'Workflows' under the WORKFLOWS section
# Click the Edit link in the desired workflow
# Click the link of the transition with the wrong title
# Click View Properties
# Delete the jira.i18n.title property from the transition.
fields.summary: Cloning a transition does not update the title of the button in the view issue screen

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30639].
  {panel}

During a data import process (like CSV), JIRA is considering "unassigned" as a new user account. So, the customer will have some issues to remove the user.

Steps to reproduce:

# Create new unassigned issue
# Import a CSV file with the following content:
{code}
Summary, Assignee, Reporter, Issue Type, Description, Priority
"Test issue", admin, admin, 1,,
"secound issue",unassigned,unassigned,1,,
{code}

After, the administrator will be unable to remove the related user account.
Also, the following [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Importing+Data+from+CSV] doesn't have something about this.

Cheers,

Paulo Renato

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30628].
  {panel}

Services need to be more isolated from JIRA as a whole, and from each other. Services need to be restartable in the event of deadlock.

Problems with the current system:

* Restarting the whole instance may require intervention from the IT department.
* Restarting the whole instance restarts all services, when only restarting one may be needed.
* An administrator can not restart a service without restarting Tomcat.
* One service crashing, will take out all others.
fields.summary: Improve service isolation

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30607].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 22 April 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

At this time, this suggestion is not on the JIRA development roadmap. We stand by our original decision to remove this feature when we redesigned issue search several years ago.

Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
[dmeyer@atlassian.com|mailto:dmeyer@atlassian.com]
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

Once again, your short sightedness on what is useful has struck again.  This is a request to put back the JQL History mechanism.   Here are some comments from the 5.2 upgrade notes page.

--------------------
JQL history is immensely useful. I'm often looking at issues and just wish to perform transient searches...searches that *I do not want to save*. The JQL history serves as a convenient place that automatically saves these *drafts*.

Another use case, when I'm fine tuning searches, I need to jump back and forth between statements to see what they produced.

Ironically, Favorite Filters are the ones I use the least because like browser bookmarks, you eventually accumulate so much that the old stuff has no meaningful purpose to you anymore, and you don't have time to unfavorite them.
--------------------
I totally agree with the feedback given by Anonymous on November 14th:  the JQL History is (was) incredibly useful when developing a good query...  and that fiddling comes *before* it is saved as a Filter.  I do not want to have to save my experiments as Filters.  That would cause problems in itself...  many of the experiments would be failures and thus just create clutter that needs to be cleaned up manually later.
--------------------
fields.summary: Restore JQL History
Document your new limits

In JIRA, users login details only stored :-
{noformat}
- lastAuthenticated
- login.currentFailedCount
- login.lastLoginMillis
- login.previousLoginMillis
- login.count
{noformat}

However, it will be better if JIRA can stored more information such as:-
- Users login time 
- Users logout time

This is useful when payroll officer track attendance of users.
fields.summary: More details on Users Login And Report Generating

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30592].
  {panel}

The JIRA 5.2, under ['View Issue' and 'Issue Navigator' Shortcuts|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Using+Keyboard+Shortcuts#UsingKeyboardShortcuts-issues], the feature of "Hides or shows the left section on the Issue Navigator" is no longer available.

Expected behavior
- The feature is not exist and trigger the keyboard shortcut "[" will have nothing happen

Suggestion
- Delete the Keyboard Shortcut in the documentation
!bug 4.PNG!
fields.summary: Documentation Error - Hide/Show is no longer available.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30590].
  {panel}

When moving an Issue between two Projects that use different custom fields, user will encounter an error. This should be handled differently, with Jira allowing the user to either cleanse the data in fields that won't be used in the new project, or cancel the move.

h3. Workaround
The issues can be moved successfully if the destination Project/Issue Type is added to the context of the User Picker custom field associated to the source Project/Issue Type.
fields.summary: NullPointerException error when moving issue between projects with different custom fields
start-jira.sh will not start JIRA with root user
Streams client backlog can grow indefinitely
LocalActivityProvider does not handle exceptions properly
Plugins is reporting a module as enabled when it isn't

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30581].
  {panel}

As seen during a JAC outage (see stack trace below).  Apparently plugins and multitenancy disagree on the plugin state.  Plugins tells us it's there, but when we try to use it the multitenancy tells us that it isn't available.  The condition is apparently permanent.  It would be a good thing to figure out why this happens in the first place, but in the meantime the I18nBean should intercept the failures instead of letting them take out the cache entirely.  If the plug-in is gone, then us not getting its translations is the right answer anyway.

I'm led to understand that this has been seen before and handled much the same way.  My guess is that this was triggered by the conversion to using Google caches, which wrap the IllegalStateException in an UncheckedExecutionException.  That's silly and unhelpful and is probably contributing to the problem.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30572].
  {panel}

Hi. I am developing a JIRA client for Android platform, and I have a few questions. 
During first launch my app caches some data in local DB (custom fields sets, value bundles for each custom field, assignee, priority etc)
There is a request in REST API - /rest/api/2/issue/{issueIdOrKey}/editmeta 
and I can get all available custom fields (with values) and operations from this request. And there is a question: is there any situation, when this request will return different data within one project? I mean different custom fields or different value bundles for two issues created in one project. And is there any way to get a Project scheme (custom fields, bundles, etc), but not a Issue scheme. 
Thank you.

*Expected Behavior in JIRA*
User able to search language in Issue Navigator. For example, search ticket with *amanhã* word in Summary/Description/Comment.

It will be great for user to search *amanhã* ticket by typing *amanha* in Issue Navigator.

fields.summary: Insensitive search on diacritics

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30562].
  {panel}

*User Recommendation*
Configure IIS to use Application Request Routing (ARR) for the reverse proxy of the JIRA Tomcat instance and besides this being a much cleaner way to host Tomcat than the ISAPI redirect. 

*Improvement Documentation*
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Integrating+JIRA+with+IIS

*Workaround*
Integrating JIRA with IIS using ARR - KB article - https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Integrating+JIRA+with+IIS+using+ARR
fields.summary: Improvement of IIS Documentation

When I click Create Issue or try to move an issue, switching the Project never works.  It constantly resets to the initial value.  Jira is nearly impossible to work with in this state.  Please note that this same problem surfaced using this public Jira instance.  So it appears that it has crept into JIRA 5.2

* User Agent: Opera/9.80 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) Presto/2.12.388 Version/12.10
* User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:16.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/16.0

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30548].
  {panel}

###Steps
1. Open dialog to create a new issue.
2. Add a code block, either by using backticks or by indenting with 4 spaces.
3. Add some ruby hash indexing code.  ie.,:

    my_hash = {}
    my_hash[:foo] = :bar

###Expected Behavior
The code block appears normally.

###Actual Behavior
Square brackets "[]" break code blocks visually.

###Affected Jira Version
v5.1#768-sha1:38ad524
fields.summary: Square brackets break code blocks.

The ability to add Custom Fields that behave similarly to the Version and Components in JIRA would be awesome.

Administrators are able to edit them and add new values per project and Users can't modify them.

h3. Workaround
As described on [this knowledge document|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/How+to+enable+Autocomplete+Renderer+for+Multi-Select+Custom+Field+in+JIRA], it's possible to add some JavaScript code to the custom field's description to enable this functionality.

*Actual results:*
When you restore a XML Backup from an instance to another the Application Links are overwritten, having to recreate the Application Links every time. (It can become a frequent problem for those who synchronizes Development - Production very often).

*What we would like to occur:* 
When JIRA is restored after parsing the XML backup, it could identify that there are Application Links and prompt a screen with the option to replace the URL's or to skip this step.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30521].
  {panel}

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 15 September 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
After discussion within the JIRA development team, we have decided not to implement this feature. The majority of use cases described are covered by JIRA Service Desk, which is a major investment by Atlassian to offer a great experience for serving customer requests, particularly the type created by emails. JIRA Service Desk offers email handlers to make this even easier.

While I understand that JIRA Service Desk is a paid product and may not be viable for all customers, realistically this issue will not become a priority for core JIRA development for the foreseeable future.

Remember that JIRA has an advanced plugin system and your license includes full access to JIRA source code, so if this is critical for you, it may be possible for you to modify your instance via other avenues.

We appreciate your understanding.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

When configuring an email handler, it is possible for us to specify the Default Reporter for creating issues from emails coming from an unknown sender. And at the moment, it is intended that the Default Reporter option will not be applied for emails coming from email addresses that has been registered in JIRA.

However, it will be great if the mail handler is able to check if the email sender have the permission to create issue in JIRA, if the user has already existed in JIRA database. And if the sender do not have the Create Issue permission, then create an issue from the mail and use the specified Default Reporter as the issue reporter. 

Sample use case: Sometimes JIRA is integrated with LDAP, and all LDAP users will be synchronized into JIRA. However, there may be a possibility that only half of the LDAP users is granted the permission to access JIRA, and the other half are not given the access to JIRA at all. And when the other half of the LDAP users is sending an email to create an issue, the emails will be rejected since the affected users do not have the appropriate permission in JIRA. 

Current workaround: Create a group in JIRA, and group the LDAP users that do not have the ability to login to JIRA, and grant the users (or the created group) the permission to Create Issue in the Permission Scheme - Does not work Post JIRA 7.
fields.summary: Use the Default Reporter configured in the mail handler when creating an issue from email, if the email sender already existed in JIRA and do not have the permission to create issues

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30517].
  {panel}

In the list of dashboard gadgets, we can find one that displays the list of favorite filters, and one that displays the results of one specific filter.

It would extremely usefull to have a gadget that can display a list of filters (like the favorites).

Our need is actually:
- a project in JIRA has many users
- the local project admin defines filters that are shared among the project members
- the local project admin defines dashboards that are shared among the project members
But there is no way to have in the shared dashboard a gadget that just lists a number of selected shared filters... 

This issue is created after contact with the support : https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-142968
fields.summary: Have a gadget that displays a list of filters

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30509].
  {panel}

Currently https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Migrating+from+Other+Issue+Trackers has information on how to use the [JIRA Importers Plugin|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-importers-plugin], however it lists the [JIRA Redmine Importer|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-importers-redmine-plugin] as not being supported [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Migrating+from+Other+Issue+Trackers#MigratingfromOtherIssueTrackers-4.RequestsforNon-SupportedImporters] and   links to [JIM-254|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JIM-254] which was resolved on 26/Oct/12 with the creation of the Redmine importer.

The problem is we still list it as being unsupported and have no docs for that plugin, which is actually supported by us. I have raised [JIM-860|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JIM-860] for the plugin devs to put together some docs, however we need to get those docs and put them on CAC so I have raised this issue.

Can you please update https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Migrating+from+Other+Issue+Trackers as well as JIRA050 and JIRA051 to have these docs? The plugin is available from 5.0.2 to 5.2.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Update the JIRA Importers Plugin docs to include Redmine Importer docs

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}

Copied from https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JIM-857

When the user chooses to create a demo project in an ondeamnd instance which does not include FECRU, the Confluence space is not created

This affects jira-ondemand-jim-bridge-plugin-1.3

The OnDemandCreateProjectHandler should be checking for which other products exist in the ondemand instance, something like this:
{code}

        builder.id(project.getId()).homeUrl(project.getUrl())
                .hasConfluence(appStatusService.isAppEnabled(Application.CONFLUENCE) && canCreateAssociatedEntityFor(Application.CONFLUENCE,getRemoteUser().getName()))
                .hasFeCru(appStatusService.isAppEnabled(Application.FISHEYE)&& canCreateAssociatedEntityFor(Application.FISHEYE,getRemoteUser().getName()))
                .hasBamboo(appStatusService.isAppEnabled(Application.BAMBOO) && canCreateAssociatedEntityFor(Application.BAMBOO,getRemoteUser().getName()));
{code}

But instead it uses the default settings, which assume that FeCru exists.

When Confluence is asked to create a project by JIRA, it looks at the project spec and fails to validate it, because FeCru is not actually there.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30474].
  {panel}

Copied from https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/JIM-856
Steps:
1. Login as a admin user having permission to JIRA Application.
2. Press GG and select "External System Import".
3. Try importing a CSV file.

Check the attached screenshot, user is not allowed to create project as earlier user needs to have access to all the products for creating product.

Apparently we now allow the project in JIRA to be created in all cirumstances: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/ROTP-547

Veenu commands us to verify that it's fixed for various supported imports.

Create subtasks via REST in a particular order

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30467].
  {panel}

Assuming the following:
# I have a project named _PROJECT_ with key _PROJ_
# I create a filter:
{code}
project = PROJECT
{code}
# If I rename _PROJECT_ to _NEWPROJECT_ then the field produces
!error.png!

*Suggestion*:
Is it possible to bind the search to the project key or issue type ID instead? That way, renaming a project should leave filters unaffected.

*Workaround*
Edit the filters to update the project or issue type names
fields.summary: Renaming a project or issuetype breaks filters saved with the old project or issue type name

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30462].
  {panel}

Big companies work differently than small companies.  If JIRA is to be effectively used by large, reliable, predictable, accountable companies, and not small ad hoc development teams "where anything goes", then JIRA must have support for business logic that goes beyond a required field here, or a workflow condition there.

Proper support for business logic means allowing the tool to have custom logic applied *before* any edit happens, so that changes to issues can be validated against business logic, appropriate for the enterprise JIRA is being used in.

Some examples:

- You might want fields to be valid in the context of values of other 
  fields.

- You might want dynamic conditions.

- You might want approval processes to be invoked, a certain role 
  may be able to lock/unlock certain fields, potentially at different
  points in the lifecycle.

- You may want fields to conform to certain formats for legal reasons.

- etc.

Support business logic at the enterprise level comes down to allowing plugin authors to gate/stop edits before they are made to JIRA issues.  

We are not asking you to implement business logic in JIRA, we are asking you to make it possible for that class of problems to be addressed by plugins.

JIRA must provide the ability to stop or alter *all* edits, not just provide notification that changes are happening.

How JIRA is failing to do this now:

Plugins can listen to changes but not actually stop or alter them.  All edits (all of them) need to be preceded by a pending edit hook of some kind to give plugins a chance to gate the edit or alter it.

This can not be done right now.  The closest you can get is using the JIRA Behaviors plugin or writing something similar where you can control the edits being made in the browser via Javascript validation, and/or in combination with server side processing.

This *fails* to provide complete support though.  A user can easily subvert business logic enforced through JavaScript:

1) do a bulk edit

2) do inline editing (if the javascript doesn't handle inline editing)

3) do edits through remote API

4) do edits through plugins (like GreenHopper)

So while a plugin such as JIRA Behaviors (which is awesome by the way), works great, it can't possibly provide *true* business logic support, no plugin can.  There is no way to gate/stop edits to issues in a way that is consistent and guaranteed to always apply.

So, ideally JIRA should provide an internal hook to plugins, which allows plugins to gate/stop/alter edits *before* they are made. 

For now though, you could solve 90% of the problem by providing a pre-edit hook inside Bulk edit.  JIRA Behaviors will likely add inline edit support, GH is using the built in edit screens now I think, and if they do remote editing...well we can tolerate that.  

So just adding a Bulk Edit pre-edit hook for plugins would solve most the problem.

Again, I want to be clear, this is absolutely necessary for enterprise customers.  Large companies focus on being predictable, reliable and accountable.  To do this, we have to enforce certain practices in JIRA, that can not be enforced simply by adding workflow conditions or configuring a few field screens.  We don't expect you to implement business logic, just that you make it possible for us to get it done, either by plugin providers or on our own.

If Atlassian is serious about addressing the enterprise market, this feature should be at the top of your queue.  Big companies work differently than small companies.

Even if you don't believe the enterprise argument (which you should), then for Agile to be a mature and disciplined approach, you still need this. Otherwise I don't think you can claim Agile is maturing.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-30452].
  {panel}

As support we find that the multitudes of different configurations with customers environments can be difficult to work with when things are not standard.

One of the things is where our customers decide to put their JIRA install and JIRA home directories. These often also either get forgotten by customers, or hands change for the organisations responsibility of JIRA, and the person who set up JRIA is no longer the person who maintains JIRA when trouble is run into.

One particular difficulty is helping a customer out with connecting to their own HSQL database:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Connecting+JIRA+to+HSQLDB

We tend to use the $JIRA_HOME and $JIRA_INSTALL variables lots in our docs, can these environment variables be set up as a standard when installing through the .bin/windows installer (or even in start-jira.sh scripts)
fields.summary: Environment Variables for $JIRA_HOME and $JIRA_INSTALL
